verse: “In the first year that Darius the Mede was king [539 bc; 5:31], I [the unnamed angel speaking to Daniel; 10:5] stood up to support and strengthen him [Michael, in his fight against the prince of Persia].

header: Kingdoms of the South and North

verse: “Now then, Daniel, I tell you the truth: Three more kings will ·rule [arise] in Persia, and then a fourth king will come. He will be much richer than all ·the kings of Persia before him [of them] and will use his riches to get power [perhaps Darius III, the last king of Persia]. He will stir up everyone against the kingdom of ·Greece [Javan].
Then a ·mighty [or warrior] king will ·come [arise], who will rule with great power and will do anything he wants [Alexander the Great, who defeats Persia].

After that king ·has come [arises], his kingdom will be broken up and divided out toward the four ·parts of the world [winds of heaven]. His kingdom will not go to his ·descendants [posterity], and ·it will not have the power that he had [not according to the dominion of his dominion], because his kingdom will be pulled up and given to other people [Alexander’s kingdom was divided among his four most powerful generals, the Diadochoi].

“The king of the South [Ptolemy I; the South is the Ptolemaic kingdom with its chief city in Alexandria, Egypt] will become strong, but one of his commanders will become even stronger [Seleucus, the founding king of the Seleucid kingdom with its chief city in Antioch, Syria]. He will begin to rule his own kingdom with great power.

Then ·after a few [at the end of] years, ·a new friendship will develop [they will enter an alliance]. The daughter of the king of the South will ·marry [come to] the king of the North ·in order to bring peace [to establish an agreement; a marriage alliance between Berenice, daughter of the Ptolemaic king, and Antiochus II Theos of the Seleucid kingdom]. But she will not ·keep [retain] her power, and his ·family [seed; or power] will not last. She, her husband, her child, and those who ·brought her to that country [supported her] will be ·killed [given up; they were poisoned in a political intrigue].

“But a ·person from her family [branch of her roots] will ·become king of the South [arise in his place] and will ·attack [come against] the armies of the king of the North [Ptolemy III waged war against Seleucus II]. He will go into that king’s ·strong, walled city [fortress] and will ·fight [act] and win.

He will take their gods, their metal idols, and their ·valuable [favored; coveted; desired] things made of silver and gold back to Egypt as plunder. Then he will not bother the king of the North for a few years.

Next, ·the king of the North [he] will ·attack [come against] the king of the South, but he will ·be beaten back [return] to his own ·country [land; the battles between the Seleucids and the Ptolemies would continue].

“His [the king of the North] sons [Seleucus III and Antiochus III the Great] will prepare for war. They will get a large ·army [multitude; horde] together that will move through the land, like a flood [powerfully and quickly]. Later, that army will come back and fight all the way to the ·strong, walled city [fortress; of the king of the South, Ptolemy IV; the fortress may refer to Gaza].

Then the king of the South will become very angry and will march out to fight against the king of the North [the battle of Raphia between Ptolemy IV and Antiochus III in 217 bc]. The king of the North will ·have [raise] a large ·army [multitude; horde], but he will ·lose the battle [be delivered into his hand],

and the ·soldiers [multitude; horde] will be carried away. ·The king of the South will then be very proud [His heart will be lifted up] and will ·kill [fell] ·thousands of soldiers [myriads; tens of thousands] from the northern army, but he will not ·continue to be successful [prevail; be victorious].

The king of the North will gather another ·army [multitude; horde], larger than the first one. After ·several [a period of] years he will attack with a large ·army [force] and many ·weapons [or supplies].

“In those times many people will ·be [rise up] against the king of the South. ·Some of your own people who love to fight [Wild/Violent men; Sons who make breaches among your people; Jewish men] will ·turn [lift themselves up] against the king of the South, ·thinking it is time for God’s promises to come true [to fulfill the vision]. But they will ·fail [stumble; falter].

Then the king of the North will come. He will ·build [throw up] ·ramps to the tops of the city walls [siege engines] and will capture a ·strong, walled [fortified] city. The southern ·army [forces] will not ·have the power to fight back [endure; last]; even their best soldiers will not be strong enough to ·stop the northern army [endure; last].

So the ·king of the North [one who invades him] will do whatever he ·wants [pleases]; no one will be able to ·stand [endure; last] against him. He will gain power and control in the beautiful land [of Judah; 8:9] and ·will have the power to destroy it [all of it will be in his hand/power].

The king of the North will ·decide [set his face] to ·use [bring] all his power to fight against the king of the South, but he will make a peace agreement with the king of the South. The king of the North will give one of his daughters as a wife to the king of the South so that he can ·defeat [destroy] him [Cleopatra was given to Ptolemy V in marriage to serve as a spy]. But those plans will not ·succeed [stand; endure; last] or help him [Cleopatra changed loyalties].

Then the king of the North will turn his attention to the coastlines [cities along the coast of the Mediterranean Sea; Antiochus was able to take some cities in Asia Minor] and will capture ·them [many]. But a commander [the Roman consul Lucius Cornelius Scipio commanded him to cease warfare] will put an end to ·the pride of the king of the North [his scorn], turning his ·pride [scorn] back on him.

After that happens the king of the North will go back to the ·strong, walled [fortified] cities of his own country, but he will ·lose his power [stumble and fall]. ·That will be the end of him […and not be found; Antiochus III died in 187 bc].

“·The next king of the North will send out a tax collector so he will have plenty of money [Then one will arise in his place who will send out a tax collector/despot/oppressor for/or to enhance the splendor of the kingdom]. In ·a few years [later/after days] that ruler will be ·killed [broken], ·although he will not die in [not by] anger or in a battle [Seleucus IV died in mysterious circumstances, perhaps killed by his brother Antiochus IV also known as Epiphanes].

“·That ruler will be followed by [Then one will arise in his place who is] ·a very cruel and hated man [despised], who had not yet been given the honor of royalty [Antiochus Epiphanes, who will be the focus of much of the rest of the chapter]. He will attack ·the kingdom when the people feel safe [without warning], and he will take power by ·lying to the people [intrigue].
He will sweep away in defeat ·large and powerful [floodlike] ·armies [forces] and even a prince who made an ·agreement [covenant; treaty].
Many nations will make ·agreements [alliances] with ·that cruel and hated ruler [him], but he will lie to them. He will gain much power, but only a few people will support him.

The richest ·areas [or people of a province] will feel safe, but ·that cruel and hated ruler [he] will attack them. He will succeed where his ·ancestors [fathers and father’s fathers] did not. He will ·rob the countries he defeats and will give those things to his followers [scatter spoil, plunder, and goods to them]. He will plan ·to defeat and destroy strong cities [against strongholds], ·but he will be successful for only a short time [until a time].

“·That very cruel and hated ruler [He] will have a large army that he will use to stir up his strength and ·courage [heart]. He will attack the king of the South [the Seleucid king Ptolemy VI]. The king of the South will gather a large and very powerful army and prepare for war. But ·the people who are against him will make secret plans, and the king of the South will be defeated [he will not stand/endure because of the plans they planned against him].

People who ·were supposed to be his good friends [eat his royal rations; Ptolemy VI’s advisors Eulaeus and Lenaeus] will try to ·destroy [break] him. His army will be swept away in defeat; many ·of his soldiers will be killed in battle [corpses will fall].

Those two kings will ·want to hurt each other [have their hearts/minds toward evil/harm]. They will sit at the same table and lie to each other, but it will not ·do either one any good [succeed], because ·God has set a time for their end to come [the appointed time of the end has been set].

·The king of the North [He; Antiochus] will go back to his own country with much wealth. Then he will decide to go against the holy ·agreement [covenant; treaty; as Antiochus returned to Syria from Egypt, he took aggressive action against the Jews in Jerusalem]. He will take action and then return to his own country.
“At the ·right [appointed] time ·the king of the North [he] will attack the king of the South again, but this time ·he will not be successful as he was before [it will not be as before].

Ships from ·the west [Kittim; Rome, which made Antiochus stand down from his attack on the South] will come and fight against ·the king of the North [him], so he will be ·afraid [startled; or dismayed]. Then he will return and show his anger against the holy ·agreement [covenant; treaty]. He will be good to those who have ·stopped obeying [abandoned; forsaken] the holy ·agreement [covenant; treaty; the pro-Antiochus party among the Jewish people].

“·The king of the North will send his army [Forces from him will arise] to ·make the Temple in Jerusalem unclean [profane the Holy Place and fortress]. They will ·stop the people from offering [turn aside] the ·daily [regular] sacrifice [8:12], and then they will set up a ·blasphemous object that brings destruction [abomination of desolation; a pagan object, perhaps a meteorite dedicated to Zeus, would be placed in the holy place; Matt. 24:15; Mark 13:14; also 1 Maccabees 1:44–47, 54 in the Apocrypha].

·The king of the North [He] will tell lies and cause those who have ·not obeyed God [transgressed the agreement/covenant/treaty] to ·be ruined [become godless]. But those who know God and obey him will be strong and fight back.

“Those who are ·wise [insightful among the people] will help ·the others [many] understand what is happening. But they will ·be killed [stumble] with swords, or ·burned [with flame], or ·taken captive [by exile], or ·robbed of their homes and possessions [by spoil]. These things will continue for many days.
When ·the wise ones are suffering [they stumble], they will get a little help, but many who join ·the wise ones [them] will ·not help them in their time of need [be insincere].

Some of the ·wise [insightful] ones will ·be killed [stumble]. ·But the hard times must come so they can be made stronger and purer and without faults […in order to refine, to purify, and to cleanse them] until the time of the end comes. Then, at the right time, the end will come.

“·The king of the North [The king] will do whatever he ·wants [pleases; desires]. He will ·brag about [exalt] himself and praise himself and think he is even better than a god. He will say ·things [fantastic/horrendous things] against the God of gods that no one has ever heard. And he will be successful until ·all the bad things have happened [rage is completed]. Then what ·God has planned to happen [is determined] will happen.

·The king of the North [He] will ·not care about [pay no attention to] the gods ·his ancestors worshiped [of his ancestors/fathers; he replaced the worship of Apollos with that of Zeus] or the god ·that women worship [desired/coveted/favored by women; perhaps Adonis or Dionysius]. He won’t ·care about [pay attention to] any god. Instead, he will ·make himself more important than any god [exalt himself above all].

·The king of the North [He] will ·worship [glorify] ·power and strength [a god of fortresses in his place], ·which his ancestors did not worship [a god his ancestors/fathers did not know]. He will ·honor [glorify] the god of power with gold and silver, ·expensive jewels [precious stones] and ·gifts [desired/coveted/favored things].

That king will attack ·strong, walled cities [fortresses] with the help of a foreign god. He will give much ·honor [glory; or wealth] to the people who ·join [acknowledge; recognize] him, making them rulers in charge of many other people. And he will ·make them pay him for the land they rule [distribute the land for a price].

“At the time of the end, the king of the South will ·fight a battle [butt] against ·the king of the North [him]. The king of the North will ·attack [rush in on him] with chariots, soldiers on horses, and many large ships. He will invade many countries and sweep through their lands like a flood.

The king of the North will attack the beautiful land [Judah; 8:9]. He will ·defeat many countries [cause many to stumble], but Edom, Moab, and the ·leaders [heads; or main part] of Ammon will be saved from ·him [his hand].
·The king of the North [He] will ·show his power in [send his hand against] many countries; Egypt will not escape.
·The king [He] will ·get [rule over the] treasures of gold and silver and all the riches of Egypt. The Libyan and ·Nubian [or Ethiopian; Cushite] people will ·obey him [follow in his tracks].
But the king of the North will hear ·news [reports] from the east and the north that will make him ·afraid [terrified] and angry. He will go to [devastate and] destroy completely many.
He will ·set up [pitch] his royal tents between the sea and the beautiful holy mountain [Zion, the location of the Temple]. But, finally, his end will come, and no one will help him.
